div.p: It isn't your typical workplace.
Employees are asked to perform a variety of tasks.
"Under certain conditions we'll also shoot a .22 pistol and a shotgun."
Many of the people who work here are highly trained engineers.
But instead of making things, they try to destroy them.
"Are you ready? All right."
The organization that causes all these accidents is a company called Underwriters Laboratories.
It was started in 1894 to test the safety of everyday products.
The tests take a variety of forms.
Each year, thousands of home appliances are tested.
Irons, toasters, blenders, and hair dryers are hit, dropped, crushed and broken.
This is to make them safe for people who don't use them carefully.
"My children, when I go home and, you know, talk about work, they think thats really neat
that Daddy goes off to work and gets to break tubes and break TVs and drop radios."
These funny tests have a very serious purpose:
to protect people from accidents that could happen.
If children play baseball in front of a TV, for example.
People have been breaking things at Underwriters Laboratories,
for many, many years, using many of the same techniques.
Each test answers a question:
Can a thief open a bank safe?
Will bulletproof glass really stop bullets?
Some of the tests are simpler than others.
"Even though we dont know all the uses a product may see,
we do have some stock tests we run on hand-held appliances."
"And one of those is the drop test."
The engineers must predict all the ways people could use an appliance wrong.
They start with the correct way to use it, and then
try to think of all the mistakes people could make with it.
At the end of the workday, UL employees collect the appliances from the days experiments.
Moments later, they are crushed one more timeâ€”to make them into trash.
It seems a fitting way to say goodbye to the place that employees sometimes call the Fun House.
